title: Privacy policy
paragraph1: This privacy policy explains why we collect your personal data and what we do with it. It also explains your rights and how to enforce them.
whoManagesThisServiceParagraph1: This service is managed by Her Majesty’s Courts and Tribunals Service (HMCTS), which is an executive agency of the Ministry of Justice (MoJ).
whoManagesThisServiceParagraph2: The MoJ is known as the data controller for data protection purposes. The MoJ personal information charter explains how the MoJ processes personal data.
whoManagesThisServiceParagraph3: As part of the MoJ, HMCTS is responsible for deciding how your personal data is used and for protecting the personal data you provide.
whoManagesThisServiceParagraph4: More information about using this service is in the terms and conditions.
whyWeCollectDataHeading: Why we collect your personal data
whyWeCollectDataParagraph1: We collect your personal data to:
whyWeCollectDataParagraph2: Our staff use your personal data to process your application. They work in the UK and your data is stored in the UK.
dataWeCollectParagraph1: When you use the apply for probate service we ask for:
dataWeCollect-item1: your name, and any other names you are known as
dataWeCollect-item2: your email or mobile phone number
dataWeCollect-item4: the names of any executors of the will
dataWeCollect-item5: contact details for all of the executors who are applying for probate
usingYourDataParagraph1: As part of your claim you’ll be asked to use your email address to set up an account. You will be able to use this email and password to sign into other HMCTS services.
usingYourDataParagraph2: We may ask for your permission to use your email address to send you emails using GOV.UK Notify. This system processes emails only within the European Economic Area until the point where emails are handed over to the email provider you use.
usingYourDataParagraph3: We use cookies to collect data that tells us about how youâ€™re using this service, including:
usingYourData-item1: if you open an email from us or click on a link in an email
usingYourData-item2: your computer, phone or tablet’s IP address
usingYourData-item3: the region or town where you are using your computer, phone or tablet
storingYourDataParagraph1: When you use this service you’ll be asked to use your email address to set up an account. You can use this email and password to sign into other HMCTS services.
storingYourDataParagraph2: Information you enter in the apply for probate service is saved until you decide to submit it. This allows you to save what you are doing and continue later. Saved information that you do not submit will be deleted after 90 days.
storingYourDataParagraph3: Information you enter in the apply for probate service will be stored for 50 years and then deleted. Wills and Grants of probate can be accessed as public records.
sharingYourDataParagraph1: If another government department is involved in processing your claim or application, we’ll share your data with them.
sharingYourDataParagraph2: If you contact us and ask for help with a service you are using, your personal data may be shared with the Good Things Foundation. This is a company who we have partnered with to offer face to face support.
sharingYourDataParagraph3: We use Google Analytics to collect our website statistics. This anonymous website usage data is shared with Google. Find out about this in our terms and conditions.
yourRights-item1: to see the personal data that we hold on you
yourRights-item2: to have the personal data corrected
yourRights-item3: to have the personal data removed or deleted (this will depend on the circumstances, for example if you decide not to continue your application)
yourRights-item4: that access to the personal data is restricted (for example, you can ask to have your data stored for longer and not automatically deleted)
yourRightsParagraph2: If you want to see the personal data that we hold on you, you can make a subject access request. This request goes to the MoJ as data controller.
howToComplainParagraph1: See our complaints procedure if you want to complain about how we’ve handled your personal data.
howToComplainParagraph2: You can also complain to the Information Commissioner’s Office if you’re not satisfied with our response or believe we are not processing your personal data lawfully.
